Award.AwardTitle: Enzymes Involved in Production of Bacterial Isonitrile-containing Natural Products

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit.
Isonitriles are organic molecules that contain a carbon-nitrogen triple bond. These molecules, which are involved in radical chemistry and are important reagents for multi-component chemical reactions, are both difficult to synthesize chemically and possess an extremely foul odor. These properties have likely limited the study and use of these interesting compounds. Surprisingly, there are many examples of biological isonitrile compounds, found in both terrestrial and marine environments. These compounds are commonly produced by bacterial pathogens, including species that infect fish, plants, insects, and mammals. The mechanistic basis for biosynthesis of isonitrile natural products has not been studied. This project will investigate the enzymology of PvcA, the isonitrile-synthesizing enzyme from a Pseudomonas aeruginosa pathway that is responsible for the synthesis of a novel natural product. This enzyme converts the amino group of tyrosine to an isonitrile, using the C2 carbon of ribulose-5-phosphate as the source of the carbon atom in the isonitrile. This research project will examine the structural and functional mechanisms of the PvcA enzymes from three homologous bacterial pathways. A catalytic mechanism for the PvcA reaction will be tested through the collaborative enzymatic and structural approaches using the crystal structure of the PvcA enzyme from Pseudomonas aeruginosa as an experimental framework. These isonitrile clusters additionally contain PvcB, a non-heme oxygenase that catalyzes pathway-specific two- or four-electron oxidations. The structural and chemical basis for differences in reactions catalyzed by PvcB will also be examined. These experiments will provide detailed mechanistic insights into the structure and function of these novel enzymes, expanding our knowledge of the synthetic capabilities of diverse microorganisms.

Broader Impact
This research project will explore the enzymatic synthesis of isonitriles, an area of research that is virtually unexplored and will therefore provide an exciting research opportunity to graduate and undergraduate trainees. Specifically, this project will support the training of two graduate students. It will additionally support multiple undergraduate students through established, highly successful summer and academic year research programs. Undergraduate students will fully participate in lab activities, will present their work and write lab reports, and will be integrated into the lab so that they understand the contribution made to the larger research study. Students will be trained to identify and address specific hypothesis-driven questions and will receive broad interdisciplinary training in the important areas of chemical, biochemical, and structural biology.

This project is jointly supported by the Biomolecular Dynamics, Structure and Function Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Chemistry of Life Processes program in the Chemistry Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All organisms rely on a shared fundamental chemistry that supports life and powers the cell. In contrast to this biochemistry of primary metabolism, many microorganisms produce a unique arsenal of secondary metabolites. These natural products are chemicals that are more specialized and often produced only by one or a few closely related species. Specific natural products play roles in microbial defense, communication, and adaptation to unique environments, including the hostile settings a pathogen experiences within a host. There is much interest in understanding the role these natural products play in the cell, the unusual chemistry of natural products, and also the proteins that are responsible for their biosynthesis. Importantly, many natural products have pharmaceutical activity and are a source or inspiration for two-thirds of the drugs that are currently in use. 

One class of natural products contain an isonitrile, an unusual triple bond between a carbon and a nitrogen atom. Many bacterial isonitriles are derivatives of amino acids. The way this triple bond is produced has not previously been elucidated and formed the basis of this research project. In many bacteria, including human, fish, and plant pathogens, the isonitrile products are produced by two enzymes PvcA and PvcB. In sequential reactions, PvcA first installs the isonitrile bond while PvcB carries out subsequent chemical changes. We have determined the atomic structures of these two enzymes.

Through the course of the work supported by this award, we have examined the specific chemical reactions performed by three different PvcB enzymes. Our work demonstrated the surprising result that closely related PvcB enzymes from different bacterial sources catalyze different chemical reactions. While the biosynthetic pathways carried out by the PvcA and PvcB enzymes from Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Xenorhabdus nematophila, and Erwinia amylovora all begin with the same initial step catalyzed by their PvcA enzymes, the fate of this initial intermediate is different in the enzymes from the different bacterial sources. We were the first group to chemically synthesize the PvcB substrate and illustrate the different reactions that were performed. Additionally, we performed the first steady state kinetic analysis of these enzymes.

Additional atomic resolution structures provided the foundation for computational docking to identify a plausible binding site for the PvcB substrate within the Pseudomonas enzyme. We then created homology models for the enzymes from alternate species. These models provided insight into the differences in the enzymes that are responsible for the alternate reaction chemistry.

This project supported the training of a graduate student in the Department of Biochemistry at the University of Missouri. Additionally, a post-doctoral research scientist at the Hauptman-Woodward Institute was also supported by this work. Finally, the project supported five undergraduate research students who worked on the production, crystallization, and enzymatic characterization of the PvcA and PvcB homologs. The project also supported outreach activities with students in the Biology Department at Niagara University. The PI visited Niagara and presented this project as part of a discussion on the use of Structural Biology to understand natural product biosynthesis. The students subsequently visited the Hauptman-Woodward Institute for a lecture and a tour.
